awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  A Smart and Collaborative Science Experimentation Tool To Inspire Future Careers in Science, Technology, Engineering and Math
awd_abstract_narration:
The innovation is a novel Science, Technology, Engineering, and Math (STEM) science experimentation tool. This sensor-based tool is a smart and collaborative system that will offer a friendly introduction to science experiments for elementary aged children. The system will be developed as a commercial product, including a game-like application to help the child interpret and control the science experiment tool.  Additionally, an educational product line for classroom use, including grade-level appropriate curriculum, will be developed.  The innovation will engage young children in exploring the world around them and provide STEM foundational knowledge and skills. The intent is to foster long-term interest and subsequent higher level study in these subject areas. 

The broader/commercial impact of this innovation will seek to produce a more technically adept workforce, by providing young children with a gentle and friendly introduction to modern technology for use during science labs and exploratory play.  The innovation will teach critical science, math, engineering, and elementary programming skills, providing children with foundational knowledge to help them excel in technical school subjects. The smart education and learning market in 2011 was worth upwards of a hundred billion dollars and is growing rapidly.  However, many of the electronic learning toys on the market dictate the answers to the child versus allowing the child to experiment and learn from the result. This innovation will encourage children to follow the scientific method before they even hear the term or fully understand the concept. Despite the commercial world benefitting from dramatic decreases in sensor costs, very little corresponding technological improvements have been made in science classrooms due to a lack of inexpensive, yet effective, educational technology based tools. This innovation will offer a low cost, engaging, and educational tool to encourage young children to explore the world around them, teaching them that the everyday world can be viewed through the lens of scientific literacy.

por.por_cntn:
Dynepic's development of an interactive, educational, and programmable toy called SensiBots developed under NSF funding caught the attention of K-12 students, parents, educators, Makers, and the local community. Each sensor-based bot (SensiBot), contains a sensor for temperature, sound, or light, forming the basis for a unique bot personality and super power. Kids will use the bots to scientifically explore their environment and learn in real engineering terms and units. The companion mobile app allows students to collaboratively control multiple bots using an If This Then That (IFTTT) graphical programming interface. This simple to use interface was at the core of the innovation and the bots screen interface would provide direct feedback to the students so they can assess the results of their collaborative programming. With the SensiBot tools developed, children 5-12 are taught STEM concepts through their own imaginative adventures.

Starting with an approachable form factor, the Dynepic team, quickly iterated over the design advancing the electronics, capabilities, software, and play patterns of the SensiBots. Feedback from public events brought a host of ideas into refining the prototypes. The most important point from the events, both girls and boys, enjoy playing with the SensiBots. Key features like clothing for the bots were added to help target the under represented female population with this line.

At the end of NSF funding there are multiple SensiBot prototypes, the Build-a-Bot 3D Printable school curriculum covering Engineering, Modeling, and Programming, and the SensiBlox for inclusion in Maker community projects. With this award, Dynepic is poised to launch the SensiBots line in a commercial environment.

Dynepic is continuing on the great work achieved through the NSF grant by building upon the foundation and expanding the vision to include the Internet of Toys. The Bluetooth Low Energy (BLE) collaborative control is the beginning of a wide network of toys that will identify each other, play together, and upgrade along with the child's progression.
